Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Quantifying Inadvertent Weather Modification and Education through Museum Programs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Atmospheric perturbations can be created by a variety of human activities. Turbulence downstream of wind turbines that produces warming and drying, the urban heat island effect, and increased dew points near irrigated agricultural lands have all been shown to be ways that human beings change the atmosphere. Although some prior studies have focused on the effects of anthropogenic forcing on local climate, few have addressed how human-induced perturbations evolve to affect downstream atmospheric flow on a variety of spatial and temporal scales. Supporting the idea that these downstream effects may be significant, previous work involving adjoint sensitivity analysis has shown that high-impact aspects of the weather, such as the evolution of midlatitude cyclones, can be highly sensitive to localized, near-surface regions where human-induced perturbations can exist. The coexistence of these circumstances, anthropogenic perturbations and their potential to grow rapidly, suggest inadvertent weather modification may be a virtually unknown reality with serious consequences. As Earth's growing population will likely exacerbate the degree of present-day anthropogenic atmospheric forcing in the coming years, understanding inadvertent weather modification now is crucial.

This research aims to gain a holistic understanding of the various means by which humans modify high-impact storm-scale, mesoscale, and synoptic-scale aspects of the weather. The approaches to achieving these goals are unique in that they focus on the interaction of estimated anthropogenic forcing and adjoint sensitivity analysis, which can effectively elucidate the important dynamics associated with different anthropogenic perturbation scenarios.


Broader Impacts
It is expected that this research will leads to an invaluable foundation of scientific results needed for society to responsibly mitigate current and future inadvertent weather modification. Similar to how the human race is currently addressing the role of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emission on global and local climate, a strong base of knowledge produced through this work can provide the information needed to strike a balance between beneficial human activities that perturb the atmosphere and the modification of sensible day-to-day weather such perturbations produce. In turn, this project has the potential to be intimately connected with the development of important government policy decisions worldwide.

The educational component of this work, which includes a museum exhibit, summer science camps, and portable educational kits for area schools, will likely make positive impacts to society well outside the confines of academia. Museums provide a casual learning environment that attracts a large number of mostly nonscientific visitors. Thus, it is expected that the museum education activities will reach many who would otherwise be unexposed to important scientific issues like inadvertent weather modification that can affect society, the economy, and the environment. In turn, this work has the potential to provide science education to the general public in a unique and effective way, improving the ability for society to intelligently address inadvertent weather modification in the coming years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to assess the relationships between the weather and human activities such as irrigation, the creation of large wind farms, and urban development. In other words, this project aimed to answer the question "can irrigation, wind farms, and urban areas affect important weather features like large low-pressure systems, precipitation, and severe thunderstorms in distant locations?" These processes, which qualify as one form of inadvertent weather modification, are poorly understood but are vital to our understanding of how human activities play a role in the evolution of the atmosphere and may have substantial ethical implications. Since activities like irrigation are known to produce small changes to the atmosphere (e.g. the addition of moisture), and since small atmospheric changes are known to sometimes grow rapidly as the atmosphere evolves, it is reasonable to expect that different types of human activities may greatly influence our sensible weather up to thousands of miles away over periods of days. This expectation serves as the main motivation for this research. Other key goals are to bring results and principles from this research to the general public through museum programs such as summer camps, an exhibit, and weekend weather days outreach events.

It was found that both irrigation and wind farms can influence atmospheric variables thousands of miles away on timescales of days. Nine case studies of model simulations with perturbed soil moisture in the Texas Panhandle within a region of frequent irrigation showed robust relationships between precipitation well downstream and the magnitude of added soil water. Further, the leading modes of nonlocal precipitation variability over subsequent days were found to relate to the degree of soil moisture well upstream for a substantial number of summertime cases. The introduction of large wind farms into the modeling domain also produced modification well downstream to large scale weather features (e.g. midlatitude cyclones), however smaller farms had negligible effects. Collectively these results highlight that while both irrigation and wind farms can modify midlatitude weather systems and convection well downstream, irrigation shows a more pronounced sensitivity and likely contributes to the day-to-day evolution of our weather. These results are published in three M.S. theses at Texas Tech University and two journal articles.

The experiments conducted in this project have also led to an unexpected and important discovery that any model perturbation produces a numerical effect that results in large unrealistic behavior that can cause grave misinterpretation of results. This effect, termed ?chaos seeding?, is caused by rapid communication of perturbations by model spatial discretization schemes, spreading small perturbations around the domain into every model variable at many times the speed of sound. These small perturbations seed all possible growth mechanisms in the perturbation experiment, leading to very rapid growth far from the initial perturbation (thousands of km) in a matter of hours. In turn, the perturbation can be interpreted to have caused these large changes when no realistic process could possibly have been involved. This phenomenon has been published in the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society with the hopes it reduces the dire consequences this effect likely has on studies examining such things as the effects of assimilated observations, model parameterizations, or any other change one might make in a model experimental framework. In this project it was shown that ensemble techniques were required to demonstrate the realistic effects of perturbations (e.g. irrigation) over that of chaos seeding.

The educational outreach portion of this project focused on the creation of a museum exhibit that focused on how our weather evolves, chaos, and inadvertent weather modification. The exhibit was entitled ?How Weather Works: The Journey from the Sun to a Storm? and was designed to explain the evolution of weather from the largest scales and processes (e.g. the Sun, the spin of the Earth, the jet stream) down to smaller-scale features we can see and feel (e.g. rain, thunderstorms), as well as the processes involved with weather modification. Several hands-on displays allowed visitors to learn atmospheric principles like the Coriolis Effect and how wind turbines can modify flow patterns. The exhibit ran for a year and a half at the Museum of Texas Tech University. Numerous week-long summer camps were conducted by PI Ancell at the museum centered around this exhibit, and PI Ancell was featured in several weekend weather days at the museum that brought atmospheric demonstrations to the community. These community outreach activities were particularly impactful since they involved cutting-edge research results, integrating research and education in tune with the goals of the NSF CAREER program.
